title: Julian Dunkerton reclaims Superdry boss mantle on permanent basis
text:
Julian Dunkerton, the founder of Superdry, has returned to head the fashion firm on a permanent basis after jumping back into the helm in April in an interim capacity.

Dunkerton - who orchestrated a boardroom clear-out, ousting former chief executive Euan Sutherland - now has until April 2021 as chief executive to carry out his 'design-led' overhaul of the troubled firm.

Investors seem to have tentatively welcomed the decision, with shares in Superdry rising by 0.6 per cent to 435.60p in morning trading.

Back in the helm: Julian Dunkerton has until April 2021 as chief executive to carry out his 'design-led' overhaul

'Julian has agreed to continue in the role to oversee the delivery of his vision to restore the brand to its design-led roots and lead the business to sustainable growth,' Superdry said.

'Today's announcement reflects the board's unanimous view that he is the right person to lead the business through this initial crucial phase of the turnaround.'

Superdry has been struggling with falling sales and sunk to an £85million loss in July after it wrote off the value of poorly-performing stores.

At the time, Dunkerton admitted that the issues in the business would not be resolved 'overnight'.

Today he said: 'Since I have returned to the business full-time, I have been working with the team to put in place the plan that will turn around Superdry, with a focus on its design-led roots and strengthening the retail basics.

'We are already seeing early signs of progress and, while this will take time, we are excited to realise the brand's full potential.'

Since April, chairman Williams has strengthened the board with non-executive appointments including former finance chiefs from Marks & Spencer and New Look.

Mr Dunkerton's base pay will remain at £600,000 a year, excluding any bonuses.

'Dunkerton certainly wasted no time in identifying the areas which needed work – namely getting back to a design-led approach, putting the right products in the right stores and improving the company's online platform,' said Russ Mould at AJ Bell.

'And he swiftly hit the reset button on the financials, downgrading the earnings outlook, slashing the dividend and basically writing off the current year to April 2020 as one of transition.

'Despite some grumbles, shareholders largely seem willing to give Dunkerton time to get Superdry back on track. But his task won't be made any easier by the tricky retail backdrop.'
